Hello Again,

I've managed to post a few photos in my album titled " Inter=
esting 
Sword."  The pictures are mediocre at best, but will hopefully show=
 
some of its charactoristics.  The grain lines in the hada 2 photo 
actual=
ly shine brightly as opposed to what is seen in the picture.
There is a bit=
 of the hamon which can be seen in the upper section 
of the hamon 1 photo.=
  The sword is in obvious need of polish.  It 
laid on the battlefield at O=
kinawa during WWll for several days 
before being discovered by a young Mar=
ine.  It was stored away with 
little or no attention since.  Oddly, the sw=
ord seemed to have found 
me as opposed to the other way around.

I'm tryin=
g to research the sword and have a little knowledge from 
research I did on=
 swords my Father brought home from WWll as a 11th 
Airborne Paratrooper.  =
I didn't realize what I was getting into!

I've had some much appreciated i=
nput from Ron and Ricky.  I still 
think judging from the Nakago condition =
the sword is most likely a 
Bakumatsu era Ko-to copy.  If anyone should hap=
pen to have opinion 
as to time period or otherwise based on the photos it =
would be again 
greatly appreciated!

Dave
